For deleting nodes, I have several suggestions. First, change the title of the node-to-be-deleted. I usually use "(duplicate) old title (to be deleted)". This helps prevent people from replying to it and also makes it less likely that some idiot^Wwell-meaning monk will consider the other node without noting that this node has already been considered. Also, make sure the doomed duplicate is not approved (and you may want to approve the non-doomed duplicated). If you have the race condition where both duplicates get considered at the same time, then you may want to temporarilly change the title of the other to "old title (please KEEP this one)".

And, of course, probably the big idea: Don't vote "delete" on a supposed duplicate unless you have looked at its duplicate, seen that it is really a duplicate and that no one has voted "delete" on that one.

I think [vroom] can undelete one of them by hand if requested not long after the delete happens.

We can already "unconsider" nodes as soon as two people have voted "edit" on a node. I almost always vote "edit" in [Nodes to Consider], so others may want to do that as well. Then you can go to [Nodes Requiring Editing] and check "resolved" to unconsider the node.

Sorry, [Petruchio], I don't know how [Tutorials] works. I was hoping that [References Quick Reference] would eventually make it to that page.

I started posting this yesterday but it got lost...

First, on the [dev] group, I was definately interested in only having [vroom] check in changes and being very conscious of minimizing the impact on his time.

I came up with a simple change that may help many of these problems. No XP changes for voter/votee after 3rd consecutive vote for/against the same person. That is, if I vote (for or against) [Ovid] ten times in a row, then only the first three votes will have any chance of gaining me XP or of raising/lowering [Ovid]'s XP. This would be another of the "unwritten rules" like how managing to vote for a node that you have already voted for doesn't do anything to XP or rep but does cost you a vote. Eventually I'd like to have this same rule apply for obvious robot votes (where the resulting page doesn't reference the nodes voted on), but I'll leave that as a separate issue.

This change should reduce the "Ack!" messages (which I consider to be the largest, though not the only, problem with "voting the person") and should make it harder to get robots advancing in power.

This would not change how votes affect node reputations at all. I could still increase the rep of every single one of [Ovid]'s nodes consecutively. This is in part to make this "unwritten rule" harder to notice and figure out so that robots aren't so likely to quickly work around it. But this is also in part because there are legitimate reason to vote the same person more than 3 times in a row and I want the "penalty" for that to be quite minor.

For the record, I don't really like my own previous proposal that much. I would really like to drastically reduce the amount of robot voting. I understand [vroom]'s reluctance to finding out who is doing it. I've investigated malicious-user problems as a system admin before and I think my feelings on it are a bit unusual. I don't want the identity to become public knowledge but I don't mind knowing. I've caught my friends doing stupid things before and I've done my share of stupid things and I can deal with being friends and having respect for someone even though I know what they've done. And I think that the current level of robot voting means that some people need to be confronted by a person who says "I know what you've done. It isn't appreciated. Please stop or we'll stop you."

Also, regarding [jcwren]'s note that dropping 1000 XP from the guilty would make their guilt known to all pretty soon. I vote for dropping the XP of any identified robots to 0 (and probably eventually changing their password). For identified robot drivers, I'd like to punish them as well after they are confronted. I think I'd probably take away their ability to vote for a 2-month period, or something.

    I think it is legitimate voting behavior to use downvotes exclusively yet conservatively. There are many people who never downvote anyone, and on the opposite side of the distribution, I see no problem with intelligent downvoting of nodes that...well...SUX0r. E.g. most of the poetry.
    This might appear as personality voting on a lot of heuristics you design. What is required is to narrow down a definition for personality voting. This seems like an utterly arbitrary problem. I haven't been around enough to hear the "proof" of the systematic downvoting so I am really pretty skeptical that it is a big enough problem to warrant this kind of attention.

    It's a common enough pattern -- one starts with a free community, something is not to someone's liking, a law is passed, and over time, the community is eventually asphyxiated by regulation.
    Thus, I support Option 2 for the moment. And if people complain that systematic abuse is continuing, vroom SHOULD go into the database. He'll find one of two things.

    • Abuse is occurring: knock the abuser(s) down 5 or more levels in XP.
    • Abuse is not occurring: knock the complainer(s) down 2 or more levels in XP.
    Perhaps include the option to appeal to a small jury of Saints.

    The core of this problem is balancing Accountability versus Freedom. Full accountability means no private votes, no private votes means whoever wields the most power and influence controls the voting.
    The only people who could theoretically do damage with systematic voting are those with multiple registered logins or those who are high-level members. You could require that Saints vote publicly. It wouldn't solve the vote-bot problem, but [vroom] could easily look for logins with a lot of XP and a very small number of writeups over a fairly significant time period.

    I semi-support the idea of upper levels having to reveal their votes. They have the bulk of the votes and the power. For instance, the Supreme Court members have to answer for their votes because of the tremendous influence the Court has on Americans (relative to the individual citizen's vote on an individual issue in a single election). The analogy is imperfect, of course, because a single Saint vote has the same value as a single vote by an initiate.

    [Adam]
    I notice one big problem with your ++/-- ratio approach. It can generate false positives. I don't usually ++ vote on nodes written by higher level monks (like saints), unless I am really impressed by the node, mostly because I know the node will get a realistic rep without me, and because the author doesn't need the xp. On the other hand, I have no qualms about -- voting a node written by a saint. They (we) should know better! So I would look like a personality voter. Perhaps that is a form of personality voting, but there is nothing malicious about it. I thing we need a solid picture of undesirable voting behaviour before automating it. Particularly repeated offense, ie someone investing more then a day or two's worth of votes to downvote one other person.

    That said, what should we do about it? I think a msg to the offender is a good response for a first offense, and could be done automatically (with the caveat of a better algorithm). A simple msg isn't really a penalty, its just a note saying, "Hey. We know about that, now knock it off." For repeat offenders, I think people will need to get involved. I'm wary of passing judgement without hearing both sides, and that requires contacting the person.

    And I disagree with [jcwren] about publishing the algorithm. A well crafted algorithm would not require hiding. I do agree with you though that the automated stuff has got to err towards the conservative.

    [jcwren]

    Personally, I'd like to really hope that whomever is the problem, or part of the problem, is not an editor.

    I'm not sure that if you develop a set of rules for determining voting habits that they should be published. It might be one of those things best kept to yourself, so that the system can less effectively be defeated.

    Obviously, we've seen lots of opinions about how -- votes should be used. Some feel that every -- should be explained at great length, other that the end of the world should occur sooner than making use of a --, or, people like me, that are fairly liberal with them when I don't like something (perl poetry, for example, generally sucks, and in my mind, is usually worthy of expending a --). However, agree or disagree, my voting habits are not the subject of this discussion.

    I can safely say that with exception of [discostu] and his alter ego, methodical downvoting is usually not my style, and I doubt that any rules that I can imagine would ever trigger on any voting I do. The problem is that they cannot falsely trigger, or they will generate massive amounts of boring discussion, and will undermine the faith in how the monastery is run. If anything, they need to error on the side of being conservative.

    While to some extent I agree with [vroom|Tim] that I don't want to know who the problem child is, I want it dealt with, and made clear that this won't be tolerated. Unfortunately, for that to occur, Tim is going to need to know who it is. I would personally elect for subtracting 1000 or more XP from whomever this is. Perhaps resetting it to 0, even. Sadly, doing so will become fairly evident to the inquisitive souls we have around here, and within a week, everyone will know who it is.

    This has put Tim in a really awkward position, as far as I'm concerned. It forces him to make decisions that he doesn't want to make, and in all probability, learn information he doesn't want to know. If you do have any idea who this is, and have some facts to back it up, I would suggest you drop a gentle note to the person in question. Preferrably before the damage done is more severe than it has been.

    [vroom]

    Voting Issues/Abuse

    Obviously a lot of people have been talking about systematic downvoting etc. The vote table can tell the tale but then what does one do with the information? Some heuristics I've thought of for finding questionable voters:

  • Up to downvote ratio between a voter and a node author:
    perhaps a ratio of 5 downvotes to 1 upvote or maybe a 10:1 ratio would be flagged as personality voting. There would probably need to be a minimum number of nodes say 25 for this statistic to hold weight. Also some users like DiscoStu would be seen as deserving of this systematic downvoting.
  • Downvote window-A sliding window of all the downvotes would be examined if 5 out of 10 say were between one voter and node_author this would look questionable.

    The last heuristic can be easily side-stepped with generous sleep()'s in the vote bot.

    The next question is what to do with the information. I don't necessarily want to know who is doing this stuff because I don't want to lose respect for people I currently respect based on this info.

  • Option 1: a script could send off /msg's from the [VoteMonitor] noting suspicious behavior and linking to a Voting Ethics page.
  • Option 2: I could post a node saying the data is all there... I can find out who is doing what. Don't make me cuz I don't want to. Stop abusing the system yada yada.
    Option 3: I could continue with the hands off approach and assume that at the end of the day good users will be able to withstand downvoting from one malicious user.

    Thoughts on the matter??
